awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Computational and Data Intensive Astrophysics at the University of Florida
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support the renewal of a 10-week summer REU (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) Site program serving 8 student interns per year at the University of Florida (UF). The REU program will leverage access to cutting-edge supercomputing facilities that include the UF’s Informatics Institute as well as the newly established AI initiative on campus. Participating students will be involved in research that will provide training in a critically emerging area for careers both within and outside the academia. The program will also provide educational opportunities outside of the laboratory to build professional writing, oral presentations, and networking skills.

The program is fully committed to working toward the recruitment, admission, training, and empowerment of a diverse REU cohort. To this end they are fostering long-term relationships with regional colleges and universities with limited research opportunities while also recruiting nationally. They intend to partner with other undergraduate programs on the UF campus to broaden the reach of these opportunities to nearly 100 undergraduates every summer.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
This project funded 8 student participants from across the country to perform research in computational and data-intensive research with faculty members and staff in the Astronomy Department at the University of Florida.  We selected students based on their responses to questions querying their professional goals, background computing experience, ability to overcome obstacles, and abilty to communicate. These projects ranged from studying extrasolar planets, to star formation, to early Universe galaxies, to cosmology, with methods ranging from observatoinal through theoretical.  While we do not yet have career outcomes for the participants (they are expected to graduate in 2024), it is clear from pre and post-surveys that the particpants demonstrated measureable gains in their ability to navigate linux, supercomputing systems, perform research with python, and in their scientific communcation skills.  Additionally, the participants engaged in value-added programming to benefit their careers, including seminars in literature reviews, scientific writing, graduate school applications, and communication.  A hallmark aspect of our program was a weekly course in building scientific talks, where every week, we would build in a new slide about their project, and by the end of 10 weeks, each student would have a full 10 minute research presentation that they could give.  The Summer culminated in a department-wide undergraduate research symposium for the Summer participants, who presented their work to the brader commuinty. 


Last Modified: 12/02/2024
Modified by: Desika T Narayanan
